sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In Ukraine, Russia says it left Snake Island to ease grain shipments.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Kyiv says it drove them out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The NATO summit ends with a formal invitation to Finland and Sweden to join, and more backing for Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: Here in the Cube, we'll take a closer look at multiple misleading claims surrounding the NATO summit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And the jazz festival in Vienne, France, opens with a French rap star and a big band.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Good evening, I'm Chris Burns.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Thanks for joining us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russian forces have withdrawn from Snake Island, a strategic island in the Black Sea, after relentless Ukrainian attacks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The island was taken by Moscow on the first day of the invasion. It sits near an important shipping lane used to export Ukrainian grain to global markets, which Western countries say is now being blocked. In announcing the withdrawal, the Kremlin said it was a, quote, goodwill gesture to allow for more grain exports. But Ukraine's military said they were forced to flee after a barrage of recent artillery and missile strikes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Details have been released on the largest prisoner swap between Moscow and Kiev since the war began.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: 144 Ukrainian troops were released, according to Kiev's military intelligence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This was in exchange for the same number of Russian soldiers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Many of the Ukrainian troops had serious injuries, such as burns and amputations, with nearly 100 involved in defending the Azovstal steel plant in Mariupol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russia says it still holds more than 6,000 Ukrainian soldiers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Joining us here to discuss the latest developments is Sasha Vakulina.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Sasha, welcome.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: These are a number of developments today but you know first of all who do we believe about Snake Island?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Did the Russians really pull back as a you know gesture to to allow the grain shipments or were they kicked out? Well this is what they say according to Ukrainian officials Snake Island has clearly come under heavy bombardment from Ukraine's counter-offensive and missiles artillery and now to prove that there are satellite image from of the past 24 hours that clearly showed those indications of an assault from Ukrainian side there is also an assessment by the Institute for the study of war that says Ukraine's expulsion of Russian forces from Snake Island is a significant victory for Ukraine as it is a significant loss for Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yeah, that leads me to that next question is, you know, strategically, what does this all mean in the strategic schema of this, right?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This is a very important place, because, of course, this will weaken any plans that Russia had about future attacks on that stretch of the coastline.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We are talking southern Ukraine. We are talking the coast of Odessa, Black Sea, and also western Ukraine, as previously said. So it makes Odessa a bit safer at this point, then? Because a lot of people were worried about Odessa. Yes and no. Yes and no, because Russia still has huge presence when it comes to Crimea, and these can still be attacked from Crimea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Okay, and then what about this prisoner swap? What was behind this deal? Do we know?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Okay, and then what about this prisoner swap?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What was behind this deal? Do we know?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, interestingly, there was no comment from Moscow about this swap.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: We do know, as you said, 95 of those returned to Ukraine were at Azov-style defenders, but in May there was more than 1,000 of Azov-style defenders that were transferred to Russian-held territory, and among them there were two British nationals and one Moroccan national as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The foreigners were now still held in the breakaway state in eastern Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yeah, and they've been sentenced to death.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: What's going to happen there?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Could there be a prisoner swap there, perhaps?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, it doesn't look like it for the moment, according to some of the leaders of the breakaway separatist state in eastern Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They don't want to do that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: That's what they say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Now, of course, there was also the European Court of Human Rights separatist state in the eastern Ukraine. They don't want to do that. That's what they say.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, of course, there was also the European Court of Human Rights that said it issued an order for Russia to ensure that two Britons captured there will not face the death penalty. But yet again, Moscow does not recognize it. So this is where we stand for the moment. When it comes to how many prisoners of war. Right. How many? Because the Russians are saying six thousand. Is that an accurate number? There is no way to verify that number. We've heard in? Because the Russians are saying 6,000. Is that an accurate number?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: There is no way to verify that number. We've heard in May from the separatist leaders in eastern Ukraine that we had over 8,000 in eastern Ukraine. 8,000 in May, according to separatists in Ukraine. Now, according to Moscow, 6,000. But when it comes to Ukrainian officials, they do not release that information. Sasha, thank you very much. Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: NATO leaders are concluding their three-day summit in Madrid this evening

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: after agreeing a new strategic concept based around a more rapidly deployable force.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Leaders pledged more military and financial support for Kiev, saying that Russia was now the most significant and direct threat to the members security Turkey also agreed to drop its veto on Sweden and Finland joining the Alliance after a deal was reached on Tuesday but their accession dis isn't a done deal yet as our correspondent in Madrid F e kotsu Costa explains the way for Finland and Sweden to finally join NATO won't be that easy why because following the celebrations the Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan made things clear saying that he expects Finland and Sweden to do specific things in order to to pass the protocol the accession protocols and to get it ratified from the Turkish Parliament what does this mean he said that he expects both countries to keep their promises and what he means what he means when he says promises is to extradite 73 Kurdish militants who are considered as terrorists from Ankara at the same time Finland and Sweden are expected in Brussels on Tuesday to sign the accession protocols. According to the Finnish foreign minister who spoke to Euronews earlier, the whole process is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Now, wrapping up NATO's Madrid summit, Jens Stoltenberg, NATO's chief, spoke about all the breakthroughs that have been achieved all these three days. And of course, the most significant one is the expansion of the alliance with Finland and Sweden with the invitations of these two countries, these two long neutral Nordic countries, and also the adoption of the strategic concept of the alliance for the next 10 years. The strategic competition of great powers is back and of course the alliance has recognized as the most significant and direct threat for the alliance, Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: And it's the first time that the alliance describes the challenges, security challenges set by China.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Efi Koutsokosta, Madrid, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Now, the NATO summit in Madrid has attracted a lot of international attention on its host country, Spain,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: but it has also become the focus for online misinformation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Our team in the Cube has been investigating some of the misleading claims.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Given all the significant press conferences at this NATO summit in Madrid, it's hardly surprising that, amid all the words, some misinformation has been spreading.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Some of these false claims might have tried to sow distrust or tensions amid the alliance, but others are simply photos that have been taken out of context.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: This is one example.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: This user on Twitter claims that even though Spain is hosting the summit, Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has apparently been given a sideline role. They claim that at a photo Pedro Sanchez was positioned in the corner and on the back row. However this photo is not from this week's summit in Madrid. You can use open source tools to try and find when that photo first appeared online.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: And as you can see on NATO's official website, it is taken back in March at another NATO summit in Brussels around one month after the Ukraine war began.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: And indeed, taking a look at so-called family photos from this week's summit, you can see that Pedro Sanchez, Spanish Prime Minister, is indeed positioned on the front row alongside NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg. That's one example however my colleague Sofia Hatzinkova in the cube has been taking a look at another false claim that concerns Spain's national security. Yes Matthew we've been seeing these

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: sorts of tweets all over social media these past few days. In it they mainly claim that due to the NATO summit Spain has declared a state of emergency and that there's this new national security law that will prevent anyone from protesting and will even tap into private citizens communications. However according to Spanish law and as you can see on the official website any state of emergency must be approved by the Congress of Deputies and then it must be published immediately in the official State Gazette and disseminated by all public media.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: So here in the Cube we checked this and we found no trace of such an announcement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: And speaking of this new national security law that would prevent people from protesting in the country, well, it simply does not exist.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_13
sentences.sentence: What does exist is an amendment that is due to go before parliament on the current national security law that takes back from 2015. But this draft does not mention in any way any prohibition of these protesting or tapping into communications. So, Chris, these are just two examples of how online misinformation has spread surrounding the summit in Madrid.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Sofia, thank you very much for doing some myth-busting there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The G20 chairman is meeting with Moscow with Russian President Vladimir Putin seeking to broker peace talks over Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The Indonesian President Joko Widodo and Putin also discussed the global food crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Widodo has invited Putin to join the next G20 summit in November despite some other western leaders saying they'd boycott it if Putin turns up.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Widodo is on a whistle stop tour which saw him at the G7 summit in Germany and a meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Hardening its media crackdown, Russia's lower house has given its final approval to a bill which will allow the banning of foreign news media.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: It's in response to other countries' actions against Russian news outlets, and it's expected to be rubber-stamped by the upper house of parliament. The move follows a law made in March which calls for up to 15 years in prison for any report seen as discrediting the Russian military.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The court of justice of the European Union has ruled against Lithuania on its national law on migrants. Under Lithuania's ruling, those found to have entered the country irregularly can be automatically detained and denied the right to asylum. But the ECJ says this violates EU laws. It has also denied Lithuania's claim it has the right to derogate European law in extraordinary situations. This comes as Poland completed the construction of a steel wall along its border with Belarus following last winter's migrant crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Travelers at the UK's busiest airport experienced further disruption today as 30 flights were cancelled.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Holidaymakers at London's Heathrow Airport were left exasperated as the airport announced the cancellations were due to high passenger numbers. In recent weeks, Heathrow had made the headlines due to severe baggage issues and long queues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Experts say Europe's ongoing aviation woes stem from the COVID-19 pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: stem from the COVID-19 pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And coming up, the 3,000-kilometer Tour de France is about to push off, this time starting in Denmark.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Stay with us and find out the details.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the show.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The European Consumer Organization is clamping down on big tech companies who are forcing people to unnecessarily share their personal data.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So that means Google is once again in the spotlight and could be fined once again.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Aida Sanchez Alonso has the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Google is driving European consumers to accept data-invasive options when creating a Google account.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That is the claim of the European Consumer Organization, which has published a report accusing the US company of this. According to the European Data Protection Law, companies should offer users the easiest and most protective option by default, what Google is not doing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: You are given two options basically. One is express personalization, one step.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The other one is manual personalization, five steps.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: As a consumer, normally what you want is to go through this process as quickly as possible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: You just want to use a certain product or a certain device.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: I'm going to take one step.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: If you click on Next and then you simply scroll down, click confirm and create your account, you have actually given Google permission to monitor everything you do on Google services and everything you do on webs and apps that use Google services.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In a coordinated way, ten European consumer associations presented a complaint against Google.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: They claimed that the language Google uses is unclear, incomplete and misleading.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And also that Google's goal is to obtain data from citizens to keep its business growing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Google's business model relies on the collection and exploitation of this data personal data for different purposes namely for targeted advertising purposes which is the main source of income for for the company now the irish data authority the country where google is based in europe will deal with the case so far it has received several fines for privacy issues in early 2022 google Google levied a 150 million euros fine over complications related to refusing cookies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And in 2019, it received a 150 million euros fine for the way it requested consent from the users.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Aida Sanchez Alonso, Euronews Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: In sports, last-minute preparations are underway in Copenhagen

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: as the 109th edition of the Tour de France gets underway on Friday on foreign soil.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The race which covers over 3,000 kilometers will also pass through Belgium and Switzerland as riders make their way to the finish line in Paris.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: To preview this, we're joined by sports reporter Michael Kern.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Michael it's that time of year again and we've got a number of people in the competition here. It's kind of a wide-open thing, isn't it? We've got Slovenian rider Tadej Pogacar in the bookies' favourites to claim the yellow jersey, but we've got Welsh veteran Geraint Thomas, who comes into the tour after a very impressive performance in the Tour de Streets. How do you see this now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, as you just listed there, some great names, some great competition. Of course, Tadej there is the two-time defending champion. He won it last year and the year before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Best stage racer on the planet right now, just 23 years old. He's got a great team around him as well. And that's something that's really important with the Tour de France. It's not just about that person who wins the yellow jersey. It's the team around them as well. So he's got a strong team and he's got Rafael Magico alongside him and Brendan McNulty and George Bennett. So certainly a strong effort from the UAE team. Emirates. You mentioned, of course, Gerard Thomas, the Ineos Grenadiers, the 2018 winner, of course, Gerard Thomas. And he's got a great team as well. Danny Martinez and Adam Yates is a former white jersey winner as well. And as you mentioned there, a great performance in the Tour de Suisse for Thomas as well. So certainly a good contender in there. He had a very strong time trial in the Tour de Suisse as well. So plenty of people to keep an eye on. A couple of other names as well worth looking out for. It'll be Ben O'Connor from AGR2 Citroën and Jack Haig, who's part of the Bahrain Victorious team. So plenty to keep our eyes on. I'm sure it's going to be entertaining as ever.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Yeah, there are lots of people behind. You know, the teams are very important, as you say. What about day four in Wimbledon? Some of the giants have fallen. What's the situation there? What are the big moments so far?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Yeah, Wimbledon. Well, for the Brits yesterday, of course, Raducanu and Andy Murray, they departed the competition. They fell by the wayside. But there's been some positive news today for the Brits. Katie Bolter, she beat last year's finalist Pishkova in three sets. That was a great battle on centre court a little bit earlier on today. Sitser Pass, he's in fine form. He's beat Jordan Thompson in straight sets today. And you may remember just a couple of days ago, Harmony Tan, of course, she knocked out Serena Williams.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: She took on Tormo today, won that 6-3, 6-4.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So she's going on very well in this competition as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: And one of the strong contenders, a new name on the scene in the men's side of the draw, Carlos Alcabath.

sentences.sentence: Another straights victory again for him yesterday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: So he's in fine form.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Yes, we'll see how Wimbledon plays out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: But there could be a fresh name on the trophy this year. We never know. Yeah, that makes it more exciting. Thank you very much, Michael. Thank you. U.S. President Joe Biden now says he backs putting the right to an abortion in the Constitution. It follows the landmark ruling by the country's Supreme Court that

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: overturned the Roe v. Wade decision that had guaranteed that right. Already, a handful of states have banned abortion, with many more planning to follow suit.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Mark Armstrong reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: By reversing the landmark Roe v. Wade decision that guaranteed abortion rights across the United States, the Supreme Court has stoked an issue that was already dividing the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Missouri in the Midwest, for example, has banned abortion, but neighboring Illinois still offers terminations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Lori Lamprich has been driving pregnant women to clinics for two years as a volunteer with the Midwest Access Coalition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: MAC provides travel and accommodation to mostly lower-income women seeking the costly procedure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It's just going to get busier. We're just going to have a lot more people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're going to have all of the folks that would have gone to the Planned Parenthood here in St. Louis that are going to be needed to be taken to Illinois.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're going to have folks from maybe mid-Missouri that would have come here to St. Louis that are going to need to go over to Illinois now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: More than 46,000 abortions were performed in Illinois in 2020, according to official data, a fifth of them on women from out of state, including 6,500 from Missouri.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Planned Parenthood estimates an additional 20,000 to 30,000 people could travel to Illinois every year.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: It's not really a big victory. Abortion is still available. We just drive around here or there or something like that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: Abortion is still available. We just drive around here or there or something like that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_14
sentences.sentence: But at least it's getting out the notion that not everybody says this is OK, not everybody agrees with this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Experts are warning that some states might try to prosecute people who help women cross state lines for an abortion.

sentences.sentence: Have mercy on us and on the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Coming up, legendary French rapper MC Solar opens up the Jazz Fest in Vienne, France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Feast your ears when we come back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Welcome back. Jazz à Vienne. It's a musical festival in the south of France, and it's known for its breathtaking ancient setting that's making its return this week with a special headline act.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Mario Boden can tell us more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: One of Europe's oldest jazz festivals returns to the south of France.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: With its 8,000-capacity Roman amphitheater, Jazz of Vienne offers an incomparable setting for listening to good music.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15
sentences.sentence: This year, MC Solar, the French rap legend, got the ball rolling.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_15

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: It's a renaissance, and the fact that we're at Jazz à Vienne is that in the early 90s, one of my inspirations was jazz. It's a renaissance and the fact that we're at Jazz à Vienne is that in the early 90s one of my inspirations was jazz.

sentences.sentence: The composers were sampling jazz or mixing jazz, that is to say rather musical than boom boom.

sentences.sentence: A flow that focuses more on the poetics rather than aggressions, MC Solar's rap draws from rock, salsa and reggae, bringing together influences from several continents.
